awd_titl_txt: DCL: HBCU: Computational Atomic Laboratory Astrophysics for Stellar and Nebular Spectral Diagnostics
awd_abstract_narration:
Atomic spectra---the unique energy signatures of atoms---carry important information about the physical conditions of the astronomical environments in which the atoms are found.  The main goal of this research project is to perform accurate calculations of key properties of atoms that are found in stars and gas clouds in space.  Accurate values of these properties will allow astronomers to reliably analyze atomic spectra from these distant astronomical objects and infer the conditions present there.  The project will train a graduate student and a postdoctoral researcher in methods of advanced computational research, and it will increase the participation of underrepresented minority students in research.

This research project will study "iron-peak" elements to better exploit them as diagnostic probes of the atmospheres of late-type stars and gaseous nebulae.  The researchers will calculate accurate photoionization cross-sections, radiative and collisional rates, and electron excitation rates for the singly charged ions Fe II, Cr II, Ti II, and Sc II using innovative computational methods and numerical codes.  Accurate data generated in the study will allow reliable spectral analysis of stellar and nebular regions because uncertainties in atomic data are thought to be a major source of discrepancy between the measured and calculated abundances of singly changed ions of the iron-peak elements.  The new data will be incorporated into the widely used modeling code CLOUDY, and they will be made available to the astronomical community via atomic databases such as CHIANTI.  The project will train a graduate student and a postdoctoral researcher in computational laboratory astrophysics techniques, and it will provide opportunities to train underrepresented minority students in advanced computational research.

por.por_cntn:
Collision of electrons and photons with atomic species is the major excitation mechanism in astrophysical objects including stellar atmospheres, planetary nebulae, H II regions, supernova remnants, and active galactic nuclei. Spectroscopic studies provide excellent diagnostic tools to understand heating mechanisms, dynamics and structures of stars, and the origin of hot gases in interstellar media. The determination of the composition, ionization state, and distribution of material in clusters of galaxies and galactic interstellar medium are important to understand galaxy formation and evolution. In this project we computed accurate radiative and electron collisional atomic parameters of iron-peak elements and other atomic species of astrophysical importance for applications to the analysis and diagnostic studies of a broad range of stellar and nebular observations.

 

The key outcome of this research project was the computation of accurate and extensive amounts of transition probabilities and oscillator strengths, photoionization cross sections, and electron collision excitation rates for many lines of iron-peak elements that are needed as input in the non-local thermodynamical equilibrium model calculations to solve radiative transfer and statistical equilibrium equations. The computed atomic parameters were estimated to be accurate enough to achieve the maximum benefit from the high-resolution observations. The calculations were performed in the close-coupling approximation using the B-spline Breit-Pauli R-matrix method and by adding spin-orbit interaction term to the final Hamiltonian matrices. During this project, the B-spline R-matrix codes were considerably modified and extended to deal with complicated iron-peak elements. The use of term-dependent, and therefore nonorthogonal, orbitals allowed us for a highly accurate atomic structure description with compact expansions that included the short-range correlation, relaxation, and various other correlation effects. The multiconfiguration Hartree-Fock method together with the B-spline box-based multichannel approach was used to determine correlation corrections accurately.

 

 We used the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE) resources, supported by the National Science Foundation grants through the course of this project, to perform most of the numerical calculations. The atomic data from the research are available to the user community in electronic tabular form at the Astrophysical Journal and Physical Review A websites.

 

The iron-group elements are known to have complicated atomic structure due to the competition between 4s and 3d orbitals and because the 3d orbitals are the first to be subjected to a collapse phenomenon. When collapse occurs 3d electrons become inner electrons leading to very strong interaction with the core orbitals. Our research provided a better understanding of many-electron dynamics due to various electron correlation and interchannel coupling effects in open 3d-shell atomic systems.

 

Finally, the other key outcome of this project was the participation of underrepresented minority students in computational laboratory astrophysics research and education activities, training, and data analysis. The Clark Atlanta University is a Historically Black College and University (HBCU) with predominantly African American student population. This project supported participation of Eight M. S. graduate students in the thesis and nonthesis research works.
